Award.AbstractNarration:
A request is made to fund additional and back-up instrumentation on the R/V Marcus Langseth, a 235? Global seismic vessel with general oceanographic capabilities. the vessel is owned by NSF and operated by Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory of Columbia University under a cooperative agreement. The Langseth is different than other vessels in the Academic Fleet in that it is a designated National Facility. It provides a unique combination of capabilities for imaging the oceans, the seafloor and the solid earth beneath the sea. It is the only vessel in the word dedicated to academic research that is capable of conducting 3D seismic surveys as well as extended offset 2D surveys. The tuned, linear source array, consisting of up to 36 airguns, with a total capacity of 6,600 cu in is also unique asset of this vessel.

Broader Impacts
The principal impact of the present proposal is under criterion two of the Proposal Guidelines. They provide infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF). The acquisition, maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2013 Ocean Instrumentation award was targeted at marine seismic towing improvements and upgrades for the R/V Marcus G. Langseth.   When operating in "3D" mode where we are towing up to 4 long hydrophone streamers that collect the reflected sounds from the seafloor and below, each of the streamers is separated by a set distance from one another. The overall width of the streamer set or the spread is determined by the towing capacity of what are called doors, vanes, or diverters that are towed by the vessel. A common brand name of these are Barovanes in marine seismic industry.  These vanes are towed are several meters high, are towed vertically in water to provide horizontal "lift" and pull to maintain cable spread much like an airplane wing does vertically. 

The acquisition of the Barovane 16's allowed us to successfully carry out a 3D Survey as planned at an unusually wide towing spread off coast of Spain that would not have been possible otherwise. With modifications made to Barovanes after purchase, we are now also able to tow them at 3 different sizes equivalent to Barovane  16's, 15's, or 8's which are progressivly smaller and give us much more flexibility in our towing setups.  

The new harnesses replace chains so are much lighter  and allow ease of towing the diverters and reduce drag of equipment.

 The smaller 50% diverters and floats are used  for towing sound source in a similar way and reducing wear and tear on source equipment.
